the best way to identify when is the best time to shift so in
this case you can see third gear I mean our our g-forces are getting smaller but
guess what they're still positive g-forces and so if I'm going to shift down into a much lower RPMs into fourth
year I have to now build those RPMs back up to before I can even get to a break
even or a match point of this so why would I want to trade More g-forces For

can up shift well you've waited too long we don't want to do that either the ideal scenario is we want to be even

and then as the RPMs wind out I increase the shift time for this area up here
this is going to be like you know if maybe you've floored it and you've
accelerated really fast and it hasn't up shifted but then you let off the throttle and you're kind of coasting
this is what this shift is for and I've more or less left it stock now the important thing here is you want
fast shifts but they should be smooth you should not get that rowboat effect
um where during this shift it takes a long time and you kind of lurch forward a little bit and then when the clutch
drops it pushes you back in the seat you do not want that rocking motion if
that's if you're getting that that's a pretty good sign that you need to lower your shift time we don't want that hard
drop of the clutch right it should be smooth this isn't the 80s we're not dealing with the shift kit that's
barking the tires we have a modern computer controlled transmission that's capable of so much we just kind of have
to help it along so again these shift times are going to dictate everything
else that happens in the transmission all these other settings are going to try to make these shift times a reality
so alter the shift times get them to where you want where you don't have that rowboat effect
the only other thing and remember I said less is more this is
all I've changed these three now I did change special but as you saw back in that other setting I
wasn't even using special I'm all in the normal section right here

desired shift time to transition from initial turbine acceleration to maximum turbine acceleration well the turbine is
the part of the torque converter that's connected to the input shaft of the transmission so whatever our shift time
is if we go back over to here
so a wide open throttle if we have 0.2 seconds for this shift a quarter of that
is going to be what half a second so in this case
um is saying a half a second of your shift time at wide open throttle we're going
to dedicate to getting that turbine to the right speed or acceleration so the only thing I've changed is I've cut it
down to 20 percent because again a wide open throttle we have more RPMs and more
torque that turbine should be able to spin up or spin down a lot faster to
make that a reality uh so one other thing I forgot to
The NoNo Zone
mention regarding the shift timing is for all of the tuning that we're doing we're only dealing with the up shift
anything related to downshift we are going to leave Factory form there's really no benefits or gains to be had by
having some super quick firm downshift that just represents too much of a risk
that we don't need and for for what there is no benefit so leave the downshift stuff alone and only focus on
the up shift this is the No-No Zone
now I said the shift timing is the most important thing and we really didn't spend a whole lot of time on that this
will be a little bit of trial and error to to bump these things around basically
you're going to want to make them um as long as possible but still smooth
so kind of maybe start out on the high side of things so if we flip back over to stock come here and then you know
you're going to slowly start working your way down to get to something that you can live with and that that feels
all right to you um and then the pressures are going to support it and this is where I feel like
a lot of people get upside down on this and what I mean by upside down is you
hear the complaint so many times I flashed a transmission it rained great
for a while but the adapters made the shifts go soft well
if your adaptives are kicking in and making your shift soft then that's a
symptom that you are upside down on your shift timing and your shift pressures
the pressures support the time so if you don't have an aggressive time meaning
these numbers are too high well then guess what happened if you command a high amount of pressure it's
going to say whoa whoa I was able to hit this shift time easily
um maybe I can knock the pressure down a little bit let me so if we're shifting
at 200 kPa well maybe I can knock it down to 175 kPa oh you know what I still
hit my shift time let me knock it down to 160 kPa and let's see if I can still
hit the shift time so it's going to keep lowering and lowering the pressure as
long as it's hitting the shift time because this is what you ask for this is what you're after you're not after a
hard shift you are after a quick shift so again the adapters are there to lower
their pressure only use the minimum amount of pressure needed to support the shift without causing excess pressure or
wear on any of the parts so if the adapters are going soft either
you need to lower the pressure or you need to decrease these shift times
so if you if you start out on the opposite which is I have a very aggressive shift time and not a lot of
pressure well the first time you shift the transmission is going to say wait a second
he commanded 200 kPa and I still didn't hit that shift time so I guess I need to
increase pressure maybe I should go up to 225 kPa to hit that Target
so if you undershoot the pressure the adapters will adapt up and that will prevent things from going soft on you so
let's talk about the pressures here there are quite a few settings and they

saying no matter what happens you're not going higher than 758 kPa so for my tune

right but if if it's otherwise stock leave them alone and the thing that causes everybody grief is this 2-3 right
it's always some wonky number why are all of these two hundreds but why and this one is 40. clearly this is a typo
but it is not leave this alone yours may not be 40 maybe it's 50 or 60 but leave

Shift Pressure
all right so let's break this down um and some chronological order of all
the things that happen before during and after the shift and then let's talk
about kind of how the pressure is all linked together and how it kind of goes Downstream so preparing for the shift we
have the ambient line pressure just in general uh being capped and maintained
by that one Max Pressure table and there's the number for that and then we
have the base pressures or the base shift pressure table and so that's kind of determined by the RPM and gear and
then it also has its other caps here so when the shift is commanded
um it says all right and by the way the shift is commanded part throttle it uses the accelerator position and vehicle
speed wide open throttle uses RPM and speed but either way whatever happens a
shift is commanded so at that point torque management kicks in and we're going to dig into torque Management in a
future video in this series but for now we're just going to say we know torque needs to be reduced for this
transmission to shift safely so after that the oncoming clutch starts
to fill with transmission fluid and we talked about this volume so the transmission kind of has a general idea
how much pressure do I have behind it and how big of a volume do I have to fill so it's going to fill that
and then if there if you if your torque converter is locked up it's going to come unlocked there is an option in the
torque converter setting to unlock it or keep it locked during the shift but assuming it is locked at the moment and
you command it to unlocked it will unlock uh off coming or off-going pressure is implied applied to disengage
the clutch and then again you know we still have the zero one two thresholds we just talked about
uh versus you know if it's discrete or not and so on and so forth
and then the oncoming clutch is applied again it's going to look at well how much pressure do I need which is going
to be determined by the engine torque initially but over time the adaptives are going to say
um well I know based off of the current torque exactly how much pressure to apply
Adaptives
um and then after the shift occurs torque management is removed in other words you
go back to normal torque if needed for criteria for the torque converter by the
way we will talk about the torque converter in another video here in this series as well if the conditions are met
to lock it up it's going to lock up and then after it's all said and done the transmission is going to sit back and
have a little retrospective and say well did I hit my shift time or not yes or no
and it will increase or decrease the adaptives as needed
so as you can see it's all about that shift time so be aggressive on your
shift time and not as aggressive on the pressure and you are going to hit that
uh now let's see this is my oncoming and off-going pressures and these are just

Flashing the Tune
okay to flash the tune once you've worked everything up it's pretty simple you probably know where this is going
we're going to click the right vehicle option I like to only flash one thing at a time
whether it's the ECU or trans I'm also going to disable the fuel pump control module here and so we're just going to
do right calibration uh avoid right and tire unless you have a specific reason
to do that same thing goes whenever you flash the ECM typically right
calibration is what you're going to be doing 99 of the time at this point I'm not going to flash it
but you would just hit the right option and on my car it takes I think 45 seconds or so once it's connected and
actually uploading the tune so I'm going to hit cancel here now after the tune is flashed I would
suggest that you need to turn the car off and take the key out close the door
and let it sit for a second to give it a second to reset and then go back in and start it from
scratch at this point you need to go into the scanner and we got to reset the vehicle
at adapt adapters word I'm hunting for so you're just going to connect to the
vehicle then you're going to click on this power icon here vehicle controls and special functions
and you're going to go to the transmission and in here we have a trans adapter reset and trans adapt preset
you're going to want to hit both of those if you have a stall converter you cannot
do a fast adapt reset or I should say a fast learn either of these avoid doing
it's not going to really help in order to make that work you have to
add the PID for the fast learn status inside of the scanner
start the car start scanning come in here to vehicle controls and do the fast adapt and then the PID I don't have it
added but it would show up over here and in the value section it's going to tell you okay idle it all right hit the
throttle and rev it up to however many RPMs are shipped into a certain gear and if you don't follow those instructions
exactly it will fail a lot of cars even on the factory transmission engine and
torque converter will still fail but essentially it's really dependent on
having the factory torque converter if you have a high stall the computer the
transmission is trying to factor in the slippage rate of the stall converter itself and it's
cycling through the oncoming and off-going clutches to figure out how much time and pressure is needed to hit
that shift time as soon as you have a high stall converter it is unable to calculate and regulate any of that stuff
so don't do the fast stuff really you're going to have to do the normal adapt reset and preset and just drive around
now the other thing is when you hit these buttons and I'm not going to do it because I don't want to reset my adaptives it may not look like anything
is happening but if you look down at your mvpi I have an MVP mvpi2 so two or
three I've never used the original but you should see the light turn from I think it's blue or green and it'll flash
that um like purple colors like the blue and the red together and when you so when you
click it watch that that light and you'll see that in fact data is being sent over the can bus to the computer it
kind of stinks there's no feedback when you click these so you just look at that light that'll tell you everything you
know so once you do that um turn the car off you know open the door close the door cycle the ignition
all that kind of stuff and then drive around and then just go easy on it for the first few miles let it hit those
shifts and let those adaptives start taking over and and getting the pressure to where it needs to be so don't don't
go Full Throttle right away but vary the throttle and RPMs use tap up tap down to
uh you know delay the shift into a higher RPM give give the transmission some data to work with so it can figure
that stuff out all right so that wraps up this video

to adjust it the larger the number okay more positive the less torque reduction
you'll have and the better it will shift now part of the reason why I have these
set so high is positive numbers is because I have kind of a large camshaft
and when the timing is too low it misfires and it coughs and sputters it
doesn't sound great but it's also a very slow recovery trying to get those RPMs
pumped back up from a low timing it's just a slow lazy recovery
so hopefully um your exhaust is set up in a way that you're able to hear those details of the
cam struggling as it tries to recover and you know keep in mind I mean I wouldn't get too too worried about it
because in the end um if you're misfiring and the engine's coughing and sputtering you're not
making any power at all so you're kind of going too far like you've gone past negative or zero foot pounds and you're
going into the negative foot pounds either way negative foot pounds is a big differential to what the car is
expecting and it may upset the apple cart so to speak so again we want that smooth quick shift and you're going to
notice it here in this low RPM range so you're going to need to set your scanner up
while you're driving and you're going to need to look at as you shift where this air mass is and now we go back to what
goes without saying you got to have the basics set up for your car for air mass so your math better be bang on and your
virtual volumetric efficiency better be bang on too now I do have another video how to tune ve virtual ve and math at
the same time using Dynamic air highly recommend you check it out because if your air mass isn't right then all this
is going to be wonky and not only is this controlling the the um the timing but it's also being
referenced in the torque the virtual torque and the the calculated torque which we will get to in a little bit so
a lot of things are dependent on your air mass being correct aside from you know your actual fuel injectors as well
okay so now let's dig in to uh this PowerPoint and kind of go
over some other finer details of this stuff too so I can explain it a little bit better
okay if you saw my last video which was the addendum to shift time and pressure you've already seen this slide before
for those that you haven't I would definitely recommend checking it out it's I wouldn't say it's required for
this video but definitely is good in general but just to recap uh so this
this 45 degree line is going to represent the ideal or perfect shift completely
neutral or maybe think about it as if you never shifted and you just kind of
continued on that same uh feel and you never shifted it just kept kind of going
this thick black line is going to represent the real world the car shifted
you're going to feel it and so this would be kind of what I would graphically represent as what a factory
shift feels like it's very safe very slow not very positive feeling just kind
of wishy-washy so when we break it down into time if the torque converter is locked it will
unlock and then we're going to apply torque management which is to say we are going to reduce the engine torque
which we'll discuss in depth today and then the oncoming clutch will fill adapters are being used the off-going
clutch will disengage adaptives are being used the turbine acceleration will
be characterized um and this is what the last video that addendum was talking about
and then the oncoming clutch will engage and adaptives are there all of those
four things are encapsulated that's like kind of internal to the transmission of
what's going on after that's done then torque management is removed which is to say the normal
torque is restored and that's external to the transmission as that's related to the engine and so that's what we're
talking about today and then optionally the torque converter will lock back up if conditions are met and it needs to do
that so this torque management here is a huge
impact of what your shift is going to feel like you can have the fastest shift
internal to the transmission but if the torque reduction isn't working together with that shift it's not going to feel
very good right this is really what you feel this torque management
so let's talk about I know we're talking about torque management today but while we're doing this wonky graph thing that
I've completely made up let's talk about Circle back to too much pressure so if you've commanded too much pressure
whether you've turned adaptives off which I would not recommend or the transmission has not had a chance to
adapt down this is kind of what it's going to feel like you're going to get that initial hey we gotta pull some
torque out we got to do the shift and then it's going to slam those clutches and it's going to be violent and you're
going to get this this oscillation this rocking back and forth just like if you botched a shift in a manual transmission
and you get that lurching and rocking and bouncing you you don't want that why haven't uh a state of the art automatic
transmission if it's going to shift like garbage now what about too long of a shift time
here we can see if it's going to take forever the car is going to slow down quite a bit and you're going to feel it
you're going to kind of rock forward a little bit and then the clutch is going to drop and then you're going to get
slammed back in your seat and you're going to get that that feel for a really slow one you're going to hear the RPMs
kind of start to flare up a little bit and we definitely don't want that
so what about no torque management so if you eliminate torque management which I
would recommend that you never do this is gonna what what it's gonna feel like and you're going to feel the normal
shift happen um and then with no torque management the engine's
still making full power but those clutches are going to engage and they're going to start to slip and then the
shaft differential between the input shaft of the engine and the input or the output shaft well I should say the
crankshaft of the engine and the input shaft of the transmission are mismatched but then they will slowly as the RPMs
bleed off from the crank and go to the transmission you're going to get that feel and I found a spot actually in my
tune I was looking at a a graph for um I was at the drag strip and I was
logging the trans uh transmission input shaft RPM turbine RPM same thing and the
the engine RPMs and you can kind of see this little blip here so we definitely don't want this to
happen either this is clutches slipping damaging and that's not good right because it's putting that friction
material in your trans fluid and it's sending it throughout the system but that slipping is also producing heat and
you know heat is kind of the enemy of the automatic transmission
so um we definitely don't want uh too much
torque management or too much torque reduction as I was saying before if you pull out too much timing it's really
that Cam that engine is going to start to cough and sputter and we don't want that easier it sounds like garbage but
aside from the transmission doing a fast shift if the engine is going to take forever to recover to get out of that
misfire then what's the point of having a fast shift you know so we want to
avoid that as well so the idea is a great shift will be
fast and smooth with minimal um impact to the feel of the car so
hitting this perfect line is probably not realistic um at least in a broad sense like you
could probably do it uh but it would take forever to dial that in for all RPMs all torque ranges
all gears that's going to be tough so you know close enough I hate to say
is what you need to aim for so balancing of torque reduction so up
here if we had no torque reduction right the clutches are going to slip as they're going to be unhappy but it's
going to feel great you're going to like the way the car drives maximum torque reduction the clutches will be happy but
you're not going to be happy with the way the car is driving and even and when I say
maximum torque reduction ideally this is going to be where the the crankshaft and the input shaft and the output shaft all
are doing the same RPM so it's a totally neutral feel to the clutches think about
the clutches so as they engage and disengage as soon as that happens is there a differential in shaft speed that

what's a super common complaint of the 6l80e you know it wants to shift but it
doesn't know if it wants to shift it can't decide if it wants to shift sometimes it does sometimes it doesn't it just doesn't know what it wants to do

out these boundaries try to keep them you know a nice distance between them and certainly no overlapping

Past videos I kind of talk about you know I I have two modes that I drive my car in one is
um I'm in town you know I'm trying to be quiet trying to be a good citizen it's a loud exhaust
it's got a big cam it's got a big stall getting off the line is a little bit of
a noisy affair right and I'm not trying to give hot Riders a bad name and sometimes I just want to drive and not
cause a big Ruckus and that's what these s-curves are so on the left side is a
really gentle you know the invisible one two three shifts get you going get you moving without a whole lot of ruckus but
then as soon as you start giving it throttle you can see that these kind of exponentially grow
and they get a lot more harder to command that up shift and so that's where you get the aggression and which
is the other side of my driving is I'm beating on this thing and I expect it to perform so to me this is a perfect blend

to manually command to downshift and RPMs are going to flare and get crazy
um I would just rather skip sport mode altogether and so in my scenario I've
just disabled this here and so now as soon as I knock that stick over into
what used to be sport mode it's automatically tap up tap down and you
inherit the transmission at whatever gear it's in so if I'm cruising off the
stoplight and I make it to third gear and I say don't shift ever again until I tell you
I just flip that stick over to sport mode which is deleted it's now tap up tap down I get the transmission in
manual mode and third gear I'm ready to go Full Throttle or do whatever crazy shenanigans that I need to do and I
don't have to worry about commanding an up or downshift to force it to get into manual mode I really like this

thing this gives us a chance to break
out early so in those high performance
situations where we have a lot of RPMs

that turbine move faster or slow down
faster right so we have the ability to
break out early and that's what this red
line represents
so putting it all together when we look
at this
our torque converter has three parts the
impeller which is connected directly to
the engine the stator which does torque
multiplication and other crazy fluid
dynamical type things and then we have
the torque converter turbine the turbine
is connected one to one directly to the
input shaft of the transmission
this orange these two things represent
the clutch right you can see they're not
touching so this is disengaged
so you know off off going clutch is
disengaged in oncoming clutches
disengaged the wheels differential
output shaft this is all just free
spinning during the shift and this part
is free spinning as well so we have
torque reduction doing torque reduction
things to the um crankshaft here slowing
down the engine but this is still
spinning and whatever fluid coupling is
going on between the impeller stator and
turbine this is doing whatever that
fluid is telling it to do some
converters are tight and they're going
to respond A Lot quickly and more uh you
know efficiently I guess to say maybe
that's a misuse of the word in terms of
converter efficiency but some converters
are going to be loose and that turbine
may be a little bit lazy at least in
some RPM or operating conditions
so
really all that we're doing here is just
characterizing this turbine because for
the factory Engineers they want that
smooth shift so you don't want a huge
differential between this input shaft
which is you know kind of fluidly
coupled to the engine and then the
output shaft to have vastly different
speeds we want to give enough time for
this shaft speed to normalize and match
so kind of like rev matching essentially
if we wait too long the car speed will
slow down and make a slow shift and
that's going to feel goofy but we need
to wait long enough to allow this shaft
to normalize
normalize its speed so again it's a
balance of speed to get smoothness
so then where does that exactly leave us
what do we do with this information and
to be honest I don't really know part of
me will say I think the correct answer
is if you have your factory torque
converter leave those transition times
alone at least if you want a smooth
shift which I would suggest doing
if maybe you've swapped out the 6l80
converter and now you have a 6L 90
converter then look through some Factory
Tunes from a 6l90 car and get a sense
for what those transition times are
doing
if you have an aftermarket converter
then you know all bets are off I would
imagine you could probably safely lower

Search in video
warning tuning your vehicle can be a dangerous activity and there is substantial risk involved the dangers
include but are not limited to permanently damaging your vehicle injury or death to yourself or other people
damaging personal property due to paying attention to a laptop while driving this
video is intended for educational purposes only before altering the
calibration of your vehicle you should verify it is in proper working and mechanical condition have a working
basis of knowledge of how your vehicle works and how the components interrelate and understand how your tuning software
works bottom line you and only you are responsible for making your own
decisions as well as accepting the consequences of those decisions I cannot
be held accountable for your actions all right my dudes welcome back to our
final installment of my 6l80e Series today is the last video we're going to
wrap everything up with just a few final thoughts and then I'm going to send you on your way to Victory Lane my brothers
all right so uh the first thing a couple tips and tricks here um is generally considered good practice
by hot rodders and gear heads to overfill the transmission by about a
quart and the reason why is under hard launches you know the fluid can slosh around and when the transmission goes to
try to pump that fluid it may find that it can't reach it so it's going to suck air and that can damage the transmission
so there are plenty of videos on YouTube of how to do that it's not that bad get
the car warmed up it's got to be between a certain temperature I I don't recall level ground you need to shift it in and
out of all the gears and then with the engine running uh you go underneath it and there's a a
plug a bolt basically that you unbolt and you know it's one of those things where it's got to drip a certain amount
not too much not too little but you kind of get a few dribbles and at that point it's considered full at that point go
ahead and dump in another quart now genetic racing they do make a dipstick and it's kind of nice the the
full line on there is indicative of an extra quart now I'm not sponsored by
Genetti I'm not sponsored by anybody I'm just a normal dude your average hot rodder you pay your money you take your
chances you learn your lessons you get bigger and better and faster and
stronger every time you fail so I don't take the money or anything from anybody
I mean hey if you want to sponsor me by all means I'll take your money right but uh I'm just gonna still tell it like it
is right so um anyway that's just one option there are other is out there the Genetti one
does look pretty much stock it's not exciting or you know action-packed or
Chrome or anything like that low carb makes one it's pretty nice and fancy but I think it does require you to drill
some holes into the firewall to mount it and for that reason I'm out dog I'm not
going to be drilling any extra holes for that type of stuff um now if you do have a aftermarket High
stall converter you're gonna need an auxiliary transmission cooler keep that fluid cool hot Transmissions
um are not having a good time so you definitely want to do that now there's some controversy involved of
okay you need an aftermarket cooler now what what a lot of guys do and I'm not a fan
of this is they're going to go out and they're going to buy the truecool 40K the biggest baddest cooler on the market
and then they are going to run the transmission lines directly to that and
then directly back bypassing everything else in the system and I'm not a fan of
that just like your engine you know they engineer it and they
design it for a specific weight viscosity of oil and that's based off of
operating temperature and the bearing clearances the transmission was not designed to be run with cold fluid it
needs some heat that's just how it was designed so I would encourage you
um and this now I'm speaking from a car perspective which you know my
understanding the cars didn't really have problems like the trucks did with the 6l80e if you're dealing with a truck
that's kind of out of my experience level so I'm don't listen to this cover
your ears close your eyes don't listen but for you car guys I'm going to say your best route is to run the lines to
the engine radiator and then from the radiator it goes to the factory thermostat and then the factory cooler
and then finally it goes to the aftermarket cooler and then that gets
routed directly back to the transmission now this has some advantages
number one when the transmission is cold running the lines through the factory
radiator is going to get that transmission fluid warmer quicker
once it's hot you know I got to imagine the transmission fluid is probably
significantly hotter than the um the engine coolant
so it's gonna get cool and you know the water to water or fluid to fluid cooling
is a lot more efficient than air to water so it's going to transfer that heat that
initial hot from that transmission to the radiator and it's going to cool off
from there it's going to go to the factory thermostat again it needs to have some heat we
can't just run super frigid air into the transmission it needs it needs the right
viscosity it's been engineered to run at a certain temperature so we want to keep that I want to say I
think for my car it was like that's 180 degree thermostat I believe something
like that um yours obviously maybe different and then you know you have the factory
transmission cooler um that's just free BTUs right you take
that and and use it I mean why get rid of it and then you can get a smaller
aftermarket auxiliary cooler so I would encourage you to keep that and you know don't take my word for it
monitor your transmission temperatures on my car is runs happy it's pretty much
like 180 degrees I mean it may sneak up a little bit on a hot day if I'm a
little hot and heavy on the throttle to 190 but rarely I think In The Heat Of
Summer does it get past 195 and that's still an exception but either way log
your transmission temps and HP tuners keep an eye on that look at it and if if you feel like you you need more cooling
then you can go and experiment from there and and try to figure something out but at least by default that's how
you should start also the lines on your your coolers should be facing up so that way air can
escape we don't want to have trapped air that's just going to prevent just like in your your normal engine coolant when
you have air bubbles heat can't transfer so you want to get rid of those air
bubbles so keep the uh the connection lines to the top not on the sides not on
the bottom you can also provide extra Cooling and fluid capacity by getting a deep pan conversion depending on you
know ride height that may be an issue I was looking at the b m one it adds 1.8
quarts of capacity and with the cooling fins they only stick apparently three
quarters of an inch lower than the factory pan so not that bad really I
mean hopefully you're not that close to the ground driving on the street anyway that's just something else to
consider so here's a picture of my setup you can see the coolers here it's mounted onto
the front bumper the internal you know bumper hidden behind the fascia and The
Grille and the a n fittings are pointed straight up and down for air to come out
OEM thermostat is in there if I ever have problems with overheating what I'll probably do
is just remove this thermostat and run without it and test it if that doesn't
work I may put it back in and then bypass the engine radiator and then if that doesn't work then may you know
bypass them both then I'll just run through the factory cooler and the aftermarket cooler but so far so good
I've had good luck it's working out good all right so the weak areas
um the factory jmbx converter is really the problem child so I found this great
picture of a cutaway view that someone did on the converter and basically you
know this is like the Piston that comes down under pressure and it can deflect
so you know we were talking about the the torque converter pressures and all that the apply ramp and all that kind of
jazz well too much pressure is going to cause it to warp or not warp but
deflector deform and so you can see you kind of have a small contact patch here
and so less contact less friction more slippage more heat so good news bad news
the friction material is this carbon weave which is very strong very tough and the fact that it's the carbon weave
well the carbon handles the heat great no problems and the weave actually allows transmission fluid to enter and
cool it even while it's locked up which is a good thing because you know locked
up you know the factory tables allow for slip so it's locked up and slipping fluid is still circulating in there
keeping it cool but the problem remains that slippage is still generating heat
and while that carbon weave says no problem I can handle the heat well that
heat has to go somewhere and so the front cover is one of those areas that
goes it's made of metal and that is a problem because here's a picture of my factory converter
and you can see these tabs this is the engine side right this is the flex plate
is right here and this would be you know facing the engine well here is the boss
that's welded on for the bolt hole and you can see it's welded on well you know
welding introduces tension and stress in the metal and when you start adding heat
it's now going to begin to Warp and as good as that carbon weave is at
dealing with heat and slipping the one weakness the Achilles heel that it has is it needs a flat smooth surface
so as the heat builds up this cover starts to warp a little bit and it just destroys that that carbon weave which is
only 20 thousandths of an inch thick and so then that carbon starts going through
the transmission fluid next thing you know you get metal to metal and bad
things happen and then you are not a happy camper by contrast here's a picture of my
personal Circle D converter and you can see it is a one piece Billet cnc'd
machined and it is a gorgeous gorgeous thing of beauty it is a shame to cover
that up with the flex plate and then throw that thing in just the bowels of the drivetrain never to be seen again
but it you know I'm happy I get to share this with you guys I hope you enjoy
looking at this as much as I do speaking of Circle D I said I would

just quick review um the shift time and pressure I think I kind of botched that first analogy I
made about you know goal and budget your goal is to shift time that's the only
thing that matters the budget is the pressure that's how you achieve your
goal and really the adaptives are in the background to say hey let me help you out I can save you some money on your
budget so don't sleep on those adaptives um the next thing is you know if the
adaptives make the transmission start going soft over time that's just an indicator that your shift times are not
aggressive enough and you commanded too high of a pressure remember old school
thinking before you had computer controlled engines and transmissions and ones that were synergistically talking
to each other there was no torque management yada yada yada
um and so how did you make those old transmission shifts fast and with
authority well with pressure but that is not the case on the new ones time is
what controls everything to shift time the pressure just how you get there
um yeah so pressure not a good thing allow those adaptives to use as little pressure as needed to get the job done
otherwise you're going to start wearing things out faster than they need to be speaking of adaptives do not change the
volumes for the adaptives on a stock transmission only do that if you've thrown in aftermarket parts and you have
the specific data even if you do change them they will fix themselves over time
but stock Parts get the stock volumes don't mess with them torque management uh there's a lot of
people will disable torque management I would highly suggest not doing that if
you would like your transmission to live a longer and happier life um torque management is also going to be
one of the biggest factors in how that the transmission feels when it shifts so
as you go through tuning you need to kind of use your calibrated butt Dyno
and and feel like well what is the difference of too much or too little torque management what is too fast or
too long of a shift time feel like what is too much or too little pressure feels
like so you should make one change at a time and kind of see how that changes
things um and then as as you start tuning more and more you're like oh you know what
that's too much too much torque I need to calm that down a little bit rather than well messing with time or pressure
or something virtual torque is also going to play a huge role in how the transmission shifts
because transmission is going to look at well how much torque is being generated
and therefore how much pressure do I need when we're making this much torque
so if you artificially so to speak increase pressure or increase torque
through virtual torque you're also going to indirectly increase the amount of pressure the transmission is going to
use as you recall I showed you some histograms that you can set up I mean I didn't go into detail but if you saw
that you should understand the gist of how to get those set up to log your torque so you can figure out how to
adjust your own virtual torque bottom line your goal as the tuner is to have a fast shift but a smooth shift you don't
want a roughed clunky uneven shift right you want full cup of coffee on the
dashboard as you shift it does not spill shift scheduling just make sure that the
Full Throttle the 100 spot on on your part throttle tables matches and meets
up with your wide open miles per hour they should basically meet you know touch perfectly dialing in wide open
throttle is going to take a little bit of time uh to determine the lead time needed to
get the shift to occur at either the correct miles per hour or the correct RPMs and as you recall I did create that
spreadsheet that will back calculate lead times for you if you just plug in a
few basic pieces of information also as mentioned before be cool Daddy-o
don't be a square use the tap up tap down you have a Super

out the slip tables add pressure as needed to prevent the slipping keep it
cool keep it under control unless you have an aftermarket converter
with a multi-disc or a multi multi-clutch I guess I should say
this late I'm sorry uh yeah multi-disc converter uh you

able to separate the pump halves and inspect the pump we'll do that in a little bit this is an area that often has issues in
these transmissions basically what happens is the torque converter in these transmissions fail
and the metal from the torque converter passes through this oil pump and it gouges up the oil pump
so it's very common that when you do an overhaul on these things you'll find an oil pump that's destroyed now there's a couple
options some people go through and they machine the pocket and the pump surfaces to
restore it and some people just go out and buy a new bell housing and pump assembly so i'm going to go ahead and pull the

transmission they have a one two three four a four five six a three five r a two six and a low reverse clutch and
they also have a low roller in this case it's a low sprag not a low ratchet or anything like that so they
have a low one-way clutch so you might assume that this is going to be the exact same power flow and
layout but this is a completely different transmission if you also remember on the 6f50 and the
6070 the middle gear set had a sun gear that was splined to the input shaft all the time so it's always
input they don't do that here they do something similar in this case they're holding a sun gear on the front gear set
but you're going to see that this is a completely different gear set completely different power flow this is actually called a lapel ta gear
train and this lapel ta gear train has a ravenal gear set in the back we'll take a look at that
when we take this apart so this is a completely different power flow than the 6t70 6f50
even though the clutch designations are the same and actually the what's holding what's driving is

the way now i'll go ahead and pull my 456 clutch
assembly apart you see we got six frictions six steels
and a wave plate and of course a backing plate we'll go back to the screw press
we got a compensator piston or a balance piston whatever you call it that is retaining the spring assembly in
there so we'll push down on it and get this retaining ring out of there got the retaining ring out
and we'll gingerly remove the piston
so here are our two pistons this is the actual 456 piston that applies the clutch this piston right here is a
balanced piston or a compensator piston and they keep this side of the
circuit filled with fluid um when this clutch isn't applied and
the reason why is if we still have residual fluid in the clutch even when it's not applied
with this drum spinning at input shaft speed that it's going to potentially create a
centrifugal force and drift that piston over and drag the clutches on but if we fill this side up with fluid
and it's trapped in there it's going to equal out you're going to have the same amount of force working on both sides of the piston
and it won't drift over and we'll rely on our return spring to keep that piston
returned back into its home position so you'll see this in a lot of transmissions it's not uncommon
but that's the reason why we have two separate pistons in this 456 clutch housing things you'll want to
inspect you do have bushings in there and that bushing is going to center itself on that 456 shaft so you got to
make sure that has that looks good and it feels good there's also a torrington bearing right there we got to make sure that's in good
shape as well typically we would put new pistons in there and obviously change the frictions out for sure and then
inspect the steels and if the steels are bad change those out as well now that we got all these parts cleaned up we can go and
inspect everything real well of course like i said earlier you want to check that bushing and
these teflon seals some builders will change them if they look good a lot of builders will just leave them they're single piece
seals so there's a tool that allows you to slide it over it fall into the groove and then there's a
sizer if they if you don't have that sizer some people will put those on there they'll squeeze them
in with their hands and then they'll wrap something around it to kind of pinch it in there uh it could be a whole like wrapped
around with some electrical tape and some hose clamp um maybe a zip tie or something but you want to shrink them down
because when you go to install the oil pump and that oil pump assembly and bell housing assembly if it goes down if it
catches on one of those and tears it you really have no way of knowing until the transmission fails on your test
drive so anyway let's go ahead and put this back together
this is that four five six apply piston we got an inner seal and outer seal there is a chamfer in this drum assembly
to allow this piston to fall in you want to just work it side to side
and it'll fall right in now before we put this compensator piston in we're going to
want to put our diaphragm type spring in there you can actually see the contact points where that diaphragm spring was
contacting that piston if this wear seems excessive it'd be a good idea to change this out
we'll gingerly install this compensator piston here in there
try to be gentle with it because the outside seal on that compensator piston will kind of guide
itself into that 456 clutch piston
but the inside diameter seal has got to kind of go across the snap ring groove
so we want to make sure that we don't tear that inner seal up
and just remember that that this compensator piston that we're installing right now it isn't a piston that applies a clutch
it's a piston really that keeps a clutch released so when the 456 piston is released
they keep fluid filled on the spring side of the 456 piston and this keeps that fluid in
there it basically seals that off and it addresses any centrifugal force that occurs
when this clutch is released remember if we have trapped fluid between the housing and the 456 piston and this housing
spinning centrifugal force could move that fluid out to the outer diameter
and apply a force on this piston we don't want that to happen because i could drag a clutch on so what they do is they have this
compensator piston here and they have it filled with fluid so if there's fluid on the apply side of the 456 piston and there's
fluid on the spring side of the 456 piston they balance each other out and it won't drag
that clutch on so now i got my retaining ring back on this piston is assembled now i can go ahead and build the clutch
assembly back up start with my wave steel friction

so how do i know when i have that drum assembly all the way down well i can measure from this thrust washer surface here down to the
bell housing from the thrust washer to the bell housing about one inch six hundred and
sixty thousands with the additional seven hundred thousandths of the thickness of this bar from this thrust washer down it's one
inch six hundred and sixty thousandths of an inch and if i use this bar laying across the bell
housing surface where it bolts up to and measure down to the surface where that three five r contacts
i should actually it should be a little deeper it should be a little bit more clearance the difference of that will be the clearance between this 350r drum
and the thrust washer that we have on this pump so it looks like i've got this all the way down
we're going to go ahead and move over to this oil pump assembly this oil pump assembly is an area of common concern with these transmissions
as i mentioned earlier these transmissions have a tendency where the torque converter clutch breaks and
and the fluid coming back from the torque converter gets diverted through the pump on its way back to the cooler and then the lube circuit so if a torque
converter fails it takes out this oil pump and there are a lot of things that people do to address that
some shops actually will go through and re-machine these parts and renew them someone will go out and
just buy new bell housings because that makes up half of the pump assembly so we're going to go ahead and take this apart and see what kind of condition
this pump is in now the service manual tells you to leave the stator support alone they don't want you to
take these bolts out they say doing so will ruin the transmission but there as you can obviously see here there's a
gasket underneath this so i mean it wouldn't be a good idea to not go through and change this out so
i know in the field pretty much everybody takes this theater support out so that they can change this gasket
and now for the big reveal this pump half here looks great there's
no scoring at all as you can see half of the oil pump exists in the bell housing so
this is where people run into a little bit of an issue if there is metal that passes through this oil pump
and ends up tearing up not only the stator half but also tears up the bell housing half so
some people go through and just purchase a new bell housing and if they're available you know you can sometimes you can find
them on amazon fairly cheap and some techs will go through and if they have the equipment they'll go through and re-machine this pump path
so obviously we've seen this pump design before this is the pump rotor in the middle these are the vanes that
go around these are little guide rings right here to kind of keep the veins pushed out
and when the torque converter through the lugs of the torque converter when the engine starts they're going to drive this pump
and it's going to create a suction on this side carry that fluid over and compress it out on the other side
and when the transmission is satisfied with the amount of pressure it's got the pressure regulator valve is
going to move into a position where it is going to enter fluid pressure into this passageway right here
basically between this pivot pin and then this teflon seal and what that's going to do is that's
going to pivot this pump and it's got a pretty hefty spring let me just go ahead and pull that gosh
let me just go ahead and pull that spring out
so what pressure on this side of the pump's going to do is it's going to pivot that outer slide and when they pivot
that slide it's going to change the amount of space that i have around this pump rotor and you can see
here this would be operating in like a maximum displacement so when this is rotating it's creating a great suction
carrying that fluid around and squeezing it out on the other side and then when they reduce the output of the pump and they
shift that slide over they've equalized some of that space around there and now it can't create as much of a
suction so it means it can't pull in as much fluid and then it has nothing to compress a compression area that gets smaller
so you basically change the expansion and compression areas of this pump by altering the fluid between this pivot
pin and that teflon seal and it's the job of the pressure regulator to control the pressure
that's in this passage right here so once pressure is satisfied the valve moves the position where it
opens up this passage and that's called decrease and it'll lower the output of the pump and it'll lower however far
it needs to control the output pressure of this oil pump we're going to look at this
pressure regulator valve line up in this oil pump because this is an area that wears out
pretty badly and transgo and sonax they've got fixes for this so if this
bore is worn out we can address it either with the transgo or the sonax kit we'll look at that a little bit later
so let's first take this apart inspect the rest of the oil pump take my pump guide rings off the little
spacer there plastic washer i'll pull my vanes out
that sounds painful pump veins not body veins
it could be pump body veins though but sealing off between the edge of the pump slide to give you a
little cut of o-ring basically to work like a spring and then a little piece of teflon seal so that those
pieces are going to ride up against this pump slide those seals live in that spot there and they make a seal between the pump slide
and the bell housing and underneath it we have this big teflon seal and then kind of like that side teflon
piece there is a o-ring that kind of also works as a spring if you will
to keep this teflon seal into contact with this bell housing and then we also have our pivot pin
looks like they've attached this spring so it's not as easy to lose because that little guy can roll pretty
far and it's so small it's easy to lose all right so we'll put those aside
this pump as i mentioned before is in great shape there's no scoring at all
if you had an issue with this where it was scored up there's metal that went through here and tore up this pump surface
some people go through and re-machine this pump and of course this side here is if it's scored up
people will chuck it in the lathe and machine it out perfectly flat or they go through and just buy new
parts but you could save a lot of money by machining these things there are a couple people out there i
think scott heatrick he machines these bell housings richard worrell there's a few of them out there that do
it in their shops so one thing if you get this machine or you buy any new parts a new slide a new
rotor a new bell housing one of the most important things that you're going to have to look at is to ensure
that these parts have freedom of movement when you bolt them together there's a specific and play
specification that exists between this slide this rotor and the half where the
the stator half bolts up to it's like one to two thousandths of an inch of end play basically the slot that
these the rotor has can only be about 1 000 and the same thing with the slide
so how would you measure that the easiest thing to do would probably put a piece of plastic gauge across this and then just lightly bolt those halves
together take it apart look to see how much has squeezed it you could also use a depth mic so if you
had a real depth mic measure down the depth measure the thickness of the rotor and the thickness of the slide
the depth has to be about one to two thousandths more than the thickness of the slide or the thickness of the rotor
that's probably something that you really want to check no matter if you buy a new bell housing or if you buy a one that was been
machined or if you're machining yourself just make sure that you're getting your one to two thousands clearance
and like i said the quick and easy would be laying some plastic gauge across there bolt it up take it back apart look to see if you've
got your one to two thousands i mean that's a typical thickness plastic gauge that we would have for engine so
we're gonna go and put this back together obviously our overhaul kit is gonna include things like our teflon seals and o-rings
you'll have to buy pump vanes and guide rings if you need those when i put this together i leave the pivot pin out for a second
so that way i can go back in with my o-ring and teflon seal
then i can pull that over with my hand and then i can slide in my pivot pin
that seems to be the easy way to do it ideally you would try to find the smallest pair of channel locks that you own to do this with
just like i did try not to nick anything up on your way in if you feel like you might have contacted something a little too firmly
you might want a little flat file across it to knock any burrs off go back together with my pump rotor
don't forget the little plastic ring that goes in there
if you're reusing the pump vanes make sure the surface that's worn all the way across is facing out towards the pump slide on
the inside you'll see it's only worn on the ends because that's where the vein rings
come into contact so you don't want that end facing out because if you have any real wear
on the outside where you can actually feel with the fingernail or just really just visually that that might introduce pump noise or
it might introduce a a pressure issue so i'm going to go
ahead and put the shiny side facing out towards the pump side
have this ready with my o-ring seal there one thing that's interesting to note really doesn't have anything to do with diagnostics is
if you stare at this oil pump you can see that from the factory they design these pumps to minimize noise
through their design if you look these vanes are closer together and then they get wider apart and they get closer and then they get
wider so it's almost random on how they place those vanes and they do that so that you don't get into like a
resonant frequency of pump pulses that hits a certain frequency that these are all
exactly the same distance apart it would have a kind of a at certain rpms it would create a
frequency that might cause a vibration somewhere or noise issue in the vehicle so by mixing up the distances between
these pump vanes they don't really create a constant frequency as this pump is spinning so you'll see that on cooling fans too like
electric cooling fans or the mechanical cooling fans on an engine in case you've never noticed that i thought that was something interesting
it's worth mentioning so we're going to go ahead and push this off to the side and we're going to move over to our stator half of the oil pump
we're going to go ahead and pull this pump stator support out and i've already taken those bolts out
so there's an interference fit here so it won't just fall apart and call me old-fashioned but i don't
like to beat on things especially when like this pump here doesn't have a gasket that goes between the two pump
halves so i want to make sure that this stays true and not warped
and so i've got my little homemade tool here i can put this in the arbor press lay a
plate across this push down so it so i push evenly off of this flat surfaces
and i do it as close as i can to the center of the stator so that way i'm trying to minimize any
warpage that i might create
it doesn't take a lot of force they do give you that gasket in the kit so you might as well take this apart so if
no other reason but to change this gasket out i do have my front bushing right here
that supports the input shaft where it comes out of the transmission i got this rear bushing where it supports the input shaft where it goes
into the 35r1234 clutch housing these ceiling rings they do come in the
kit one thing that you don't want to forget is that there is an o-ring seal that lives under there it'd
probably be worse if you took it out and then forgot about it and never put a new one in than it would be if you didn't realize
it was even in there to begin with but the o-ring keeps pressure out on these rings
these are non-rotational rings which is different from the very early
design so this is something they added to it the non-rotational rings will
lug into these notches and that will prevent this from spinning the ring from spinning so the drum
will spin and slide around the surface right here if it was a rotational design pressure would go underneath that seal
push the ring up against the surface and the ring would spin within the stator groove
and stay kind of connected to if you will or at least pressured up against the three five power clutch housing
but they don't want that in this they use the non-rotational design so that the drum spins around a
stationary seal so you'd want to go through and change your rings and the o-rings behind those for each of
those so some of these earlier units these
6l80s they have these rotational rings and you saw on this transmission that it had
non-rotational rings and with the rotational rings when pressure gets in between these passages to apply clutch pressure
gets behind those rings pushes those rings out and they grab onto the drum and they spin with the drum
so the non-rotation rings obviously since they're notched in here pressure can get behind them but
basically the outside of the ring and the drum make the seal they changed this design from the rotational ring to the non-rotational
ring because they had cross leakage issue transgo in their 6l80 valve body kit
includes these rings that as you can see get kind of tangled up here but and they have a new teflon seal scarf
cut as opposed to these uh plastic type what that has like a notch cut in it so they
got the teflon seals with a scarf cut and then they also have these expander
rings and these expander rings go in the groove first i'm just going to do this top one because this is a lab unit
but you lay this expander ring down in there and the key is is to make sure that
these little pieces of wire don't overlap each other when they're in there you don't want the wires to cross you want just to lay in
there like a nice spiral because if they cross it's going to hold that teflon seal out further than it should
once that expander rings in there you could take a little bit of transgel put it inside this groove that we've got
you can take your new teflon seal and remember that the scarf cut has to kind of match up there you don't want
them overlapping the wrong way this is how it's supposed to go you don't want to go that way and then just
make sure your scarfs kind of match up and you have
them pushed in there with your against that trans gel you do that on
all three now you've dealt with the cross leak issues without having to replace the stator

assembly and that uh replaces their the original aluminum boost valve assembly and built into this boost valve assembly
they add a pressure relief so that if pressures ever spike and they have figured that
pressures have a tendency of spiking that's what causes damage in these transmissions if the afl pressure ever spikes and that
passes through the pressure control solenoid and finds its way here at the boost area of the pressure regulator valve this is a relief valve
it's going to blow off that excess pressure so you don't over pressurize the transmission and cause failure so this is a really nice
modification once again even if i had a pump that really didn't have any excessive wear why wouldn't you install a valve like
this because you're dealing with an issue that's going to happen later on down the road so it's a great setup to
go through and put this in and you're making the final product better than it was originally the parts that they're not
going to use the original pressure regulator valve the original pressure regulator spring the boost valve the original boost valve
and its sleeve so those parts do not get reused about the only things that you're

456 clutch solenoid and that is often

um computer where that's actually

there

Hydraulics
now I'm going to cover a few hydraulic
things before we get deep into the

why I'm doing that is because I think

transmission operates hydraulically now
I do have a complete hydraulic lesson on
this transmission but I'm just going to
give you a couple tidbits here that we
need to look at before we get into this
tuning in this AFL valve right here it's
responsible for controlling pressure to
the solenoids I just went through and
showed you all those different solenoids
well those solenoids don't receive full
line pressure they're going to receive a
reduced pressure determined by this
valve the actuator feed limit on this
hydraulic schematic that's actually a
picture of the AFL valve as it would sit
in the valve body it receives line
pressure but the pressure that finds its
way out is a reduced pressure well I
shouldn't say it's reduced it's actually
limited it just won't go as high as line
pressure can go line pressure can go
well over 200 PSI on this transmission
but the AFL pressure as I have listed
here it's going to be somewhere between
110 and 125 psi Max so that way we're
not going to bombard these solenoids
with more than let's say 120 PSI or so
the operation of this of this AFL valve
is actually pretty simple line pressure
is going to find its way into this
passage and find its way out into the
AFL circuit FL pressure that lets in
that line pressure should say that gets
its way into the AFL passage is going to
find its way to the end of that valve
right there and then when that moves
this valve over far enough it's going to
end up blocking off its passageway it's
not going to let any more of that
pressure in
that's how it regulates itself it's all
determined by the strength of that
spring
so this spring tension right here is
what determines the ultimate AFL
pressure the reason why I mentioned this
is because when we start tuning things
we're going to see some little sections
where we can change the values of the
pressure values in this transmission the
first one we're going to look at today
is called MAX Pressure a and you're
going to notice it's it's set from the
factory at like 110 PSI
well there's nothing in this
transmission that's going to operate
that low other than
these little solenoids right here the
solenoid pressure so

actually telling the computer what our
AFL pressure is and we're going to go
through when we do our tests we're going

Line Pressure
or not
so actuator fee limit pressure is
important but so is line pressure and
the way we generate line pressure in
this transmission is this pump assembly
that we have it's a variable output pump
and it rotates the center section which
is called a rotor rotates you can see
the arrow it's going to rotate clockwise
it's drawn here and that's going to
allow fluid to be sucked in from the pan
through the filter and kind of enter
this pump cavity right there so as this
rotates we get like an expanding area
and that creates a suction and then when
it comes around it squeezes off and that
compresses the fluid and pressurizes it
pushes it through the line pressure
circuits if we look up top here we've
got a pressure regulator valve one of
the areas that that line pressure goes
to is on the top side of this line
pressure valve that's actually going to
push this valve down and work against
this spring this is a fixed spring
that's in there so you always have to
overcome that spring when that valve
gets pushed down that line pressure
eventually is going to find its way into
this passage right here called the
decrease passage if you follow it down
it goes to the outside of this pump
slide so once they have enough pressure
as determined by the pressure regulator
valve the excess pressure Finds Its way
into this decreased passage and it
pivots this pump slide over there's a
pivot pin right there and a seal right
there so when fluid Finds Its way into
this section right there
it's going to Pivot this outer pump
slide over when it does that it's going
to equalize the space around this pump
rotor and when we equalize the space
around the pump rotor we're not going to
be able to create a suction to pull
fluid in and we're not going to have a
collapsing area to compress it out so
that limits the pressure
now how we change the pressure in this
transmission is we have a line pressure
solenoid it receives that 110 to 125 psi
the actual actuator feed limit pressure
and it delivers that depending on how
the solenoid is being operated it
delivers that into this pressure control
solenoid line pressure passage that
Finds Its way into this boost valve and
fluid pressure the 100 basically zero to
let's just say 120 PSI is going to work
itself on the bottom side of this boost
valve and it's going to add Force to
that spring so not only will line
pressure have to overcome the tension of
that spring but it's also going to have
to overcome whatever boost pressure that
is added to this valve lineup so when
they operate the solenoid when they turn
the solenoid on and they pulse would
modulate the solenoid but when they
pulse would modulate the solenoid onto
its Max it's actually going to have no
fluid pressure in here so it's going to
have to overcome just the spring tension
they pretty much never operate it under
that circumstance and then as they turn
that solenoid off the more off I create
it so it's a normally open solenoid as
they turn the solenoid off that allows
more of that AFL pressure into the
circuit so as pressure builds up more
line pressure is going to be required to
overcome the spring and the pressure
that we have in the Boost fail circuit
in order to get to the point where it
will regulate itself and reduce the
output
so that's just kind of a quick brief

Clutches
now looking at the 6l80 or 6l90
transmission and really 6l50 as well
it's got three driving clutches
the driving clutch is a clutch is taking
engine torque through the torque
converter and is driving a part of the
gear set then we have two holding
clutches and a holding clutch is a part
that holds a part of the gear set to the
transmission case then we have a one-way
clutch which is used to hold the carrier
for first gear so our three driving
clutches are the one two three four
clutch so it's applying first second
third or fourth the three five R so it's
applied in third fifth in reverse and
then the 456 clutch which is applied in
the fourth fifth and sixth gears and our
two holding clutches the two six clutch
and the low reverse clutch and our
one-way sprag this is what they call a
range reference chart but because the
names are pretty easy to follow you can
as long as you know the names of the
clutches you pretty much already know
what's applied and when
so to reiterate I know I already
mentioned this but we have our one two
three four clutch three five R and four
five six clutch those are the driving
clutches
three five r one two three four housing
so the four five six clutch assembly
is actually part of the drum
that is connected to the transmission's
input shaft
then we also have a couple holding
clutches the two six is a holding clutch
as I mentioned before and the low
reverse
so this two six clutch is part of this
Center support assembly
and on the other side
is the low sprag right here in the
middle
and then the low reverse clutch is
located around it
those are our two holding clutches
it's worth mentioning all that because
there's a lot of modifications that you
can do to these Transmissions internally
you might find hardened shafts or
different Pistons some Billet Pistons or
some different quality clutch components
that you can change around and another
reason why it's important to mention is
and we'll cover this when we look at
clutch clearances is because there are
sections on HP tuners where you can go
through and change and modify the clutch
volumes if you will and every one of
these clutches are going to have a
certain amount of
piston movement
which means it's going to displace a
certain amount of volume when we go from
off to on
and that's going to be determined by the
clutch pack clearance that I've got
so you can imagine how important it is
that a we are we have our clutch pad
clearances set right and B that we
understand that those volumes that are
listed in HP tuners or just in their
general program that's going to inform
the computer of how much of a piston
stroke is going to occur before this
clutch pack clearance is taken up so if
you're ever taking these things apart to
rebuild them definitely measure your
clutch packs clearance and make sure
they are within specifications
Clearance
you know the the clearances are not a
huge range so that's 48 to 70 thousands
and here's 60 to 78 thousands
then it looks like 50 to 74. that's and
then 51 to 81 so that's the biggest
range on the low reverse that they give
you actually low reverse isn't even that
important because that's not a
synchronized shift but all these others
you're seeing maybe twenty four
thousands 18 to 24 thousands of a window
of clearance and in my opinion you
wouldn't want to be on the extreme ends
of either one of those
specifications either
Shift Feel
so what controls the ultimate shift feel
in this transmission I mean that's our
main goal here using HP tuners and
changing the tables is we want a firmer
shift we want a maybe even a softer
shift I don't know depending on what you
guys want but what are we actually how
are we controlling that and what's uh
the transmission doing to kind of give
us a quality shift well one of the
things that we'll note is that a 6l80
6090 doesn't have any accumulators if we
look at older Transmissions they've got
these spring-loaded accumulators that
give kind of a fluid place to go to
provide a cushion so that way the clutch
applies a little bit less violently or
can apply Softly
the 6l80 and 6l90 it does not have any
accumulators so one thing that they do
have that pretty much all transmissions
have is a piston return spring so when a
clutch is released we want that piston
to be to be retracted all the way in its
bore and then when we apply the clutch
we're gonna have to overcome whatever
spring is holding that piston back so
that can actually work as a cushioning
device to a point and in these clutches
also they have wave plates they've got
plates that are not they got steel and
friction steel and friction but the
bottom they usually have some kind of a
cushioning device something to take the
impact off of that clutch so it doesn't
jar when it applies and in most cases
it's either a dish plate or it's a wave
plate so that is another form of
accumulation that they've got they also
have orifices in the valve body so the
spacer plate between the valve body
halves some of those holes are going to
be engineered to a certain size and
that's going to control the rate of
fluid application through that plate and
by controlling the rate they can control
how quickly fluid enters the circuit
they can control the apply rate
and then lastly we're going to talk
about what's most important because it's
something that we have control over with
HP tuners is the clutch pressure control
so the applying or oncoming clutch and
the releasing the off-going clutch
pressure is going to control the shift
quality now looking at these different
phases The Fill phase is kind of
self-explanatory that's when the clutch
assembly is filling up with fluid and
you're maybe stroking that piston just
to the point where those frictions are
about ready to touch so they estimate
the amount of time it's going to take to
fill that and then the next phase you
could see is kind of just running right
off of the end of that fill phase is the
torque phase and the torque phase is
that portion where there's no ratio
that's changing but we're we're getting
the off-going clutch to release
and then we've got the oncoming clutch
kind of building up pressure and taking
hold then this inertia phase right here
is when the ratio actually starts
changing so
by the time the ratio the the speed
ratio is changing we're going from a low
gear to a high gear if that's an up
shift we're expecting the off-going
clutch to be off and then during this
inertia phase the oncoming clutch to
basically apply so this is actually that
shift time that we observe when we feel
like a three-tenths of a second shift or
something like that that's going to be
the portion because we're actually going
to feel the engine speed drop and the
ratio change during this inertia phase
and then lastly when the clutch is
finally applied and we don't see the
ratio change anymore they go into this
torque holding phase or the final
portion the final holding torque holding
you'll find different names for it but
these are the really the four different
phases of a shift and when we look at
some of the pressures I'm going to kind
of almost combine this fill and torque
phase because I think that kind of runs
into each other and there's it's harder
to tell the division between those two
when you're looking at actual pressure
readings this right here is a forward
patent and they're basically showing the
same thing where when we look at the
oncoming clutch we've got that fill
phase and then we've got the torque
phase and then when that off-going
pressure drops off we start the inertia
phase and that's when the ratio changes
and then once that ratio is done
changing we go into that final holding
stage
or that torque holding stage whatever
they want to call it

back in this transmission overnight so

off-going pressures that's going to be

so along those same lines we're going to
release the clutch in different stages
just like when we apply a clutch we've
got The Fill torque inertia are then
holding we're going to have to have
stages for the releasing clutch because
on these synchronous Transmissions you
have to control the releasing clutch
it's just as important as controlling
the apply clutch because I can't let a
releasing clutches drain off immediately
because for a period of time I'm not
going to have any clutch applied and if
I didn't have any clutch applied my
engine would flare and I can't hang that
pressure on too long because if I got
two clutches applied or trying to
operate in two gear ratios at once it'll
bind the transmission up so that's the
reason why when we look at these
pressure curves there's a systematic
approach to releasing the pressure and
applying the pressure so that way they
get a precise perfect shift
it's also why these Transmissions
sometimes have quirky shifts here and
there is because it's pretty easy for a
tie up to occur or for a flare dough
curl curve
so these presets just like we were

is that the ultimate goal is to have this transmission slip at whatever the
desired slip amount is so they're going to look at actual slip speed by comparing engine speed and input shaft
speed and they're going to change the pressure in the torque converter clutch to match the desired slip speed so if
the desired slip speed is 20 RPM they're going to manipulate pressure to get 20 RPM of slip and here in lies the problem
is that I have a stock vehicle with no modification having gone through and increased the torque of the engine that
would cause it to slip more I gone through and changed the torque inverter with a different friction lining haven't
put any shift kits in it that alter maybe the spring tensions or valve sizes or anything like that so there's no
modification so me going through and changing some of these values might not yield any result so it's going to look
like some of these things didn't have any effect on the transmission at all when in fact they might have an effect
if I had a modification that I was trying to compensate for that increased torque or a different friction material
