a bit and that's the reason why the the pressure has got to fluctuate a little bit here and there during that process
so I wanted to point that information out because torque clutch operation is not a precise science they obviously
have tables and logic and methods but when we go through and look at what's happening we see this slip speed and
they don't want just the slip speed to be at zero they don't want to just turn the torque con clutch and have it apply they want this torque conter to slip a
little bit because that's going to dampen out some vibrations it's going to have a smoother operating vehicle
smoother operating transmission so in these low gears like in first and second gear you could see they apply the torque
re clutch and they don't fully apply matter of fact they let it slip more than normal even though this is staying
at 20 hour PM you could see that it pretty much fluctuated around 100 maybe a little under 100 RPM slip until this
next shift occurred and then it dropped it down and was kind of trying to maintain that 20 RPM slip and you could
see a lot of hash there where they do a lot of ping ponging back and forth they look at the slip if it's a little too
high they raise the pressure if it goes a little too low then they lower the pressure they're constantly chasing its tail almost like the fuel system does
when it's trying to maintain fuel control rich and lean rich and lean they wait for an oxygen sensor to read lean
and then they add more fuel then they wait for it to go rich and then pull Fuel and they constantly Chase itself
around like that same thing is happening in this transmission for the torque converter I wanted to point that out and
I wanted to point out that there's so much more that this transmission has to work with you can see I'm at 54 PSI and
I'm doing the 40% Baseline stock configuration but I'm at 40% throttle producing a decent amount of engine
torque yet all I'm needing is around the 50 50 to 60 PSI to keep that torque
converter clutch applied to give me 20 RPM slip so this thing actually has a lot more room a lot more pressure that
it could generate to apply that clutch if it needed to so if you download the

roughly 4/10 of a second they'll bring it up to over 100 PSI and then you'll see another pulse once I'm actually
cruising on the road you can see when pressure went up I was actually driving the vehicle on the dyno Wheels were
spinning and before they brought the converter on they actually pulsed it

and then they slowly brought that pressure up and that was to control the slip speed on all these different graphs

2nd Mod - TCC Apply Ramp
we modified was a Ply ramp see it right there under the torque converter clutch pressure so you click on that you get
this table up across the top it says slip RPM error so this is how far off
the slip RPM is from desired and on the side here we've got RPM which I assume is either engine RPM or input shaft RPM
but either way based off of what the err is if let's say for example desired is 20 RPM and I'm getting 40 RPM so that
the difference would be 20 and depending on what my engine RPM is this this is how much pressure they're going to add
to the torque converter clutch to try to bridge that Gap and bring it back down to where it's supposed to be as it gets
closer it would switch over to 10 and then five then once it's perfect it theoretically You' think it'd be zero
and then if it overshoots it it'll subtract a certain amount of pressure so that's what the idea of the ramp is and
if I increase these values it's going to give you more apply pressure to try to
bridge that Gap so if you're going through and you're modifying your engine power your torque output or you know
you've supercharged turbocharged your engine or something like that that under the given tables if they see a slip air
and they're going to apply the clutch with a certain amount of pressure that might not be enough to bridge the gap so you would in fact want to go in there

Overall TCC Mods Summary
this whole torque converter clutch modification now I want to preface by saying that a lot of people that are
tuning these things they tune all the slip out especially if they're putting an aftermarket converter in there and they've got maybe a paper type friction
uh on the on the converter clutch and at the end of this presentation I go over the inside of this tor converter so you
can see what I'm talking about as far as paper and woven carbon and all that kind of stuff but um if you're going through
modifying this transmission and you've got high performance High horsepower or you're concerned about torque converter
clutch a wear issues go ahead and tune this thing where there's no slip at all but if you're trying to maintain that OE
feel where it's smooth and you don't feel that torque clutch apply you're probably going to want to keep that slip
in there you might turn it off so it's not slipping in all the gears like this one here you could see the torque clutch
applied in first all the way through sixth or you might you know some people just turn it off first second and third
gear and only let the torque of clutch apply in fourth fifth and six some only let it apply in fifth and six but if you
decide to keep it pretty much in a standard format and you're just trying to manipulate and modify based off of
any kind of changes that you've done to the engine or the transmission we'll just realize that
some of these settings here may or may not actually result in any kind of a change since the vehicle I was using was
stock didn't really see hardly any changes except maybe at the very initial portion of that application of the
torque converter clutch and as I mentioned a million times the computer is going to make the actual slip speed
match to the desired and it's going to pulse with modulate that torque converter clutch solenoid to deliver
whatever pressure it needs to make that happen and I want to point out that these transmissions by Nature they apply
this torque clutch very early and they keep it applied the whole time they don't hardly ever disconnect it until
you're below a certain speed and almost at a stop and as I mentioned throughout this presentation the slip speed is
probably some hidden tables in there that we don't have access to because initially like when you're in first and possibly second gear they allow a little
bit more slip and then they even go to less slip when you're in higher gears and uh wide open throttle a lot of times
they'll bring the slip not necessarily to zero even if stated that in the table but they're going to try to bring that
slip a little bit lower so we don't have access it seems to every table but of
the tables that we do have access to you have the ability of controlling some slip and another thing which is pretty
amazing is that the torque converter clutch pressure listed on the scanner especially when you get up into the 50s
60s and 70s 80s you know that pressure range it's actually really accurate to what the
actual torque clutch apply pressure is and it's pretty amazing in my opinion
that this thing works as well as it does and it's not even using all the pressure that has uh that that's available to it
as we saw usually if at wide open throttle on average the pressure got into the mid 80s but this thing could
easily achieve 140 PSI if that torque conter clutch solenoid actually want it
to so there there's more room for adjustment and movement yet it gets it
done with a relatively low pressure I know I say that 85 PSI will put over
7,000 pounds of force on that piston but and you're going to see coming up here
how this torque converter actually operates and works and the parts and pieces and some of the upgrades some of
the Billet pistons and the Billet covers and some of the different friction materials so here is a six lady torque

so you can look at the inside and I cut it along the weld there actually kind of
off to the side so that way we can study what's going on on the inside of this converter this is the converter
cover so this is the surface right here that the friction material comes into contact with that ply piston moves
towards the engine and applies up against this nice smooth surface here
this cover you can see there's the mounting pads that's where the flex plate is bolted to the torque inverter
cover so this is always driven by the engine and then when we apply the converter piston and it pushes up
against this nice smooth surface here it's going to deliver torque through the Piston through dampening Springs right
to the input shaft of the transmission and this is the turbine for the 6l80
it's got splines on the inside there that spline to the input shaft of the transmission if I flip this around you
could see that pie-shaped converter piston is right here and with that converter piston you can see the
friction material they use here is this woven carbon fiber the benefit of this
woven carbon fiber is that when they apply pressure up against this thing even when it's touching the cover fluid
can Wick its way through this friction material and pull he heat away so that's
the benefit of it that's the reason why they can get away with running slip on this converter continuously when we
think of this whole surface area area that we've got and we actually measure across this diameter of the friction
material which is 11 in and we subtract the 2 inches from the middle this thing's got over 90 in of surface area
90 square inches of surface area if you multiply that by 85 PSI which is something that we've seen in this torque
converter that's over 7,800 lb of force
that's pushing up against this converter cover so that's just stock configuration
under normal operation it's not enhancing anything or kind of uh beefing
anything up that's just using stock pressures and a stock configuration on driving the vehicle at wide open
throttle like we would expect so it's generating over 7,000,000 lbs of force
up against this piston pushing it up against the cover and because of that many Builders will opt to put an
aftermarket converter cover in which is Billet so this is is this is a Billet
chunk of Steel that they machine this cover out of you can see the pads they're machined out of this material
they're actually they're not welded like the OE converter is and it's thicker it's a thicker chunk of Steel other then
this piston is also thicker and so there's less deflection
less flex and that is what a lot of people attribute the converter failures
to D in this uh transmission so this is a nice upgrade a Billet cover and a
Billet piston so the two different types of friction material that you'll find that these people rebuild them with is
either this woven fiber or the cellulose or paper design a lot of aftermarket
converter Builders will use this cellulose or this paper design when they're rebuilding these converters a
because they're more comfortable with it and B because it's thicker it's comes in a couple different thicknesses but it's
thicker than the the woven fiber and the reason why that becomes an issue is because sometimes they have to machine
that piston and remove Material off it or if they're reusing a cover they're going to have to machine the cover well
that obviously takes up some metal and and the woven carbon fiber doesn't come
in thicker pieces but the paper friction material not only does it come in different sizes but it's also
automatically thicker and uh it will replace some of the space that's lost by the metal but an issue might arise that
if you're using a paper friction material in a place where there's supposed to be a woven fiber and you
don't remove the slip that this might end up overheating or glazing and then giving you some drivability issues so if
you were to change the friction material from the woven fiber to a paper design
it's probably a good idea to remove that slip in these tables and force this converter just just lock up like they
did in the good old days but if you want the drivability to be the same as it was
in a stock vehicle in configuration you're going to want to use that carbon fiber now it's not a big deal if if you
use that carbon fiber and you upgrade to that Billet cover and that Billet piston
because those won't deflect like the original converter does and they'll be able to handle the more torque the more
uh pressures and so forth so nothing NE nothing wrong with this woven carbon fiber but if you're ordering a converter
from a builder or a you know supplier make sure you know what you're getting if you're going to get a carbon fiber
lining or a paper lining or request one or the other and if you got some real power you can opt to put the big dog in
there and have your Builder build the converter with this this is a Billet cover and a Billet piston but what makes
it special is that it's got a multiple disc clutch assembly in there so you actually have three surface friction
surface areas as opposed to just one so if you look this piston lugs into the
cover it's got a woven carbon fiber friction material on this side and then what lugs into the Piston
is a double-sided friction disc so this one
has um a kind of a more of a high performance heavy duty feel to
it so I wanted to point out the differences in these converters because you have options and there's heavyduty
converters that are using Billet covers and Billet pistons and different types of friction material in it there's stock
converters that are stamp steel Pistons stamp steel covers and they have woven
fiber um friction lining it which is perfectly fine but you need to know
what's going on what what you have in the vehicle when you're tuning this because if you're going to tune it with
slip or tune it without slip it helps to know what kind of friction material you have and how this converter is
built

You said:
hello my name is sean boyle and i teach here at southern illinois university and this video is about the 6l80 6090 heavy
duty performance kit offered by transgo it is entitled the tow and pro kit
and some of you guys that rebuild transmissions you're really going to appreciate this kit because it includes some of their individual kits plus it
includes a few extra goodies to basically beef up this transmission and make it work for a heavy-duty situation
like towing or racing now i want to go through and say a special thanks to our recent graduate arleigh coleman he was a
student of mine in the transmissions class and he took on an extra project and he did all the muscle work in this
video pulling a transmission out tearing it down cleaning everything up putting it all
back together putting it back in the vehicle and running it on the dyno and i want to say special thanks to him
without all the extra work that he did we wouldn't have been able to make this video also thank you transgo for sending
me this kit so that way we can go through and evaluate it now we have a cts-v here donated to the program
fortunately we cannot drive it on the road but we do have an all-wheel drive dyno so we've been running this thing on
the dyno we ran this vehicle before we took it apart and kind of collected some information then we took the
transmission out took it apart installed the programming kit reprogramming kit and then put it back
on the dyno and we've got our little first impressions there of this kit and i'll tell you right now the kit is muy
bueno very good so this is a kit from transgo and you can go to transgo.com and learn more about their products
specifically we're covering the 6l80 tow and pro and you can see here transgo has been around making
transmissions better for 60 years and this is 2022 that this video was made so that's pretty impressive 60 years of
making transmissions better good job transgo we're going to go through and we're going to look at this kit this kit
is a combination of a couple of their individual 6l80 kits plus some additional stuff that they use for the
heavy duty kind of application in the racing application and it also has
information on tuning if you use efi live or hp tuners it gives you some suggested changes that
you can do in the tuning software that'll complement this kit now talking with transgo they said you do not need
to doing it you could just install this kit it'll work fine it'll work great even without a tune but if you want to
make it perfect consider using that software and tuning it and they have some videos on
specifically what to change and i'll show you those later in this video now this product is called their
toe in pro you can see here drive tow race so you got a little bit of everything so if you've got a heavy duty
application like a truck or you got a corvette or a camaro or something like that that you've got this transmission
you're planning on racing you might consider installing this kit i'll tell you right off the bat that the transmission does have to be removed
from the vehicle it's just not a valve body kit you have to pull the transmission out so you can pull the bell housing off and get the pump apart
because there's essential parts that you need to change in the pump and you can't get to those parts unless you pull the
transmission so if you don't plan on pulling a transmission do not install this kit because the parts in the valve body work
in conjunction with the parts in the in the pump and if they were mismatched you're gonna have problems so
plan on doing the whole thing and while you're in there you might as well go through and freshen it up and their instructions which by the way
transgo has kind of revised their site in the last couple years where they've added their instructions to their kits
right here under documents you click on it you can pull down their instructions and you can see kind of what you're up against on their website they show a
nice graph of what the their kit actually does the pressures in this transmission and you can see over here they show that that transco pressure is
a little bit higher and that gets you that firmer shift like you like and then the shift pressure here which is really
what kind of controls the smoothness of the shifts you could see that the trans
go through their boost valves that you're going to see later on in this video how they manipulate the pressures
in there to make for a nice smooth shift and as i mentioned before their instructions are available on their
website and they're really good they're good learning tools right there you can go and download these instructions even
if you're not planning on rebuilding a transmission you can learn a lot just from reading the instructions not only do they have the repairs and the fixes
and all that but they explain some stuff here and there and they kind of describe common problems and what to look out for
now the towing pro it's a pretty big instruction sheet it's like 12 pages long but

so here we have the oe pressure regulator valve and the transom pressure regulator valve and you can see some
differences for one the construction this is an anodide the oe uses an anodized aluminum

that the boost valve will ride in and their steel valves and of course steel springs but now if you also look
see all the additional surface area they've got here they've got all this additional surface area right here on this valve and then
they add on the surface material here and this extra material that i got on this transo valve is going to ride on
unused metal in this pump and this as we know from previous videos
and so forth this oil pump suffers from a lot of wear and especially this valve suffers from a lot
of wear so it's really imperative when you overhaul these transmissions that you deal with the oil pump wear and this
transgo deals with it by adding material to the valve so that this new fresh material rides an unused
portion of our previously unused portion of metal that was in the oil pump
now the other things that we could see that's different that that hole right here connects to the end of this valve
and that's going to be there because this is a relief this area in this pump right here is a relief where when oil pressure gets in there it gets exhausted
out there's actually a passageway right through the pump it's not a magic trick i'm able to find a hole
put that right through and that's also the reason why they have a notch cut out is that when this thing moves over far
enough to the point if that original valve land right here ends up blocking
this and prevents oil that's in the decreased passage from finding its way out it can always
sneak out through that so this ensures that also that oil can find its way out to the exhaust if that
situation happens another thing they do different on this unit is that
they've got a hole drilled through the line pressure land
and that goes all the way over to the end of the pressure regulator valve
so just like the traditional gm pressure regulator valves pressure that gets into that hole can find its way to the end
and that's the regulating end so this part right here is what receives line pressure and it creates a force that's
going to compressing the spring this spring here that lives on that end
it's going to compress that spring and that's going to determine minimum line pressure
then the pressure that comes from the boost valve side is going to determine pressure rise
so in summary the modifications that transgo made to these valves is a added
material so that way the valve can ride in previously unused material in the pump bores
and they added these oil passages to allow oil to drain out through the spring end of the valve when needed
and to allow line pressure to find its way over to the reaction land to actually start compressing the spring

inch thousands of a square inch so now when we divide
55 thousandths in the 566 pounds of force we end up getting about 103
psi so the pressure from this afl valve
circuit and this transo valve is much lower and that's kind of pulling some information together for us because when
we think about afl pressure and if you don't know this stuff you can look at some of these other lectures that are
more on the theory and operation of the 6l86 l90 got all those videos up there but
afl pressure feeds all the solenoids feeds the torque over clutch solenoid it ultimately ends up controlling the
pressure that goes to a lot of these clutches and to the torque motor clutch so when we start looking at some of the
numbers that transgo had for like line pressure for example it seemed like the line pressure would be much higher but
if they're lowering their afl pressure that will kind of bring things back into kind of a a baseline
more of a comparable pressure same thing with even those boost valves that we've got
because our solenoid pressure being delivered to those boost valves might be a little bit lower
because our afl pressure is a little lower and only thing i can guess is that they're doing this to protect some of
the transmission because there's so many areas with the torque converter clutch and also
the 350r drum and the one two three four piston these are all areas that are known to break
so maybe they attribute that to this um afl valve and with the blow-off valve
that they entered into the boost valve circuit in the oil pump that all kind of maybe works together to kind of keep
that under control so we don't get crazy pressure spikes in this transmission i think i think makes sense it makes
things probably a little bit smoother as well yeah so a little smoother operation i do know with talking to transgo they
spend a lot of time engineering these springs so that there is a smooth transition
from low to high especially with things like the torque vertical clutch solenoid because there is a sweet spot that the
solenoids like to operate in and they designed the springs to operate well within that sweet spot that was
something that they explained to me on the phone and before we finish this off we've got
a few more end plugs that we can put in and they end up going into the one two three four
regulator the 35r clutch regulator and the 456 clutch regulator bore
and after those get put in we're going to go through and assemble these two halves
and we'll call it done [Music]

through and add the recommended tune that trans go kind of recommends on their videos and we're going to run it
on the dyno again and see how things changed now this is the original table found under shift timing when you're in

these top six rows to 500 milliseconds and then the bottom rows below that to 200 milliseconds
and the way you read this description down there it's kind of misleading it says shift time input torque adder one
two then it says it adds to the desired shift time based on input torque and engine rpm now

the values that you get here is pretty much the shift time that shows up when you actually drive this vehicle on the
dyno just to give you another example this is off of a 2016 silverado pulled the shift table information off of it
and you can see the values are different so uh it's going to be different for different vehicles the
stock values but transgo just kind of recommends the 500 200 and when we go through and modify it you can see
everything those top six rows ended up going to 500 milliseconds and then those
lower three rows go to 200 milliseconds and basically what you're looking at is the calculated torque based off of the
engine rpm which cell or value are you going to fall within so at your higher rpm your kind
of your race mode they're going to be looking for a 200 millisecond or a fifth of a second shift time and then when
you're at lower speeds uh kind of cruising around you're gonna have kind of more
you know half of a second shift which is kind of a more common shift time that you would see i usually
you know typically you see between 400 and 500 milliseconds so this would be giving you more of a comfortable shift
or a smooth shift when you're just doing normal driving but could you give you that nice tire tripping with the smile

move up and down
around this stationary inner lifter if

and the valves will remain closed and
then when they want this to engage again
they'll release the oil pressure
and the spring that exists between those
two plungers will push the plungers out
and it'll grab into the outer body
and then now the body will push that
inner lifter and it'll travel and
operate just like a normal lifter would
that's the way that they're designed

problems that exist with displacement on
demand
as far as our transmission operation is
concerned well
if you look at the way how these
transmissions are operated software wise
they'll bring torque converter clutch
operation as early as first gear
and um so first second third all the
gears all six gears on a 6l80 6l90
could potentially have torque converter
clutch application well displacement on
demand
isn't really a gear driven component
it's more of a load-driven
component so if you're lightly on the
throttle they might apply your torque
converter clutch in second gear
or third gear and then also start to
apply this four-cylinder mode
and next thing you know you're
transmitting all these vibrations into
the cabin of the vehicle so
vibrations at low speeds when the torque
motor clutch is engaged
that is a very common complaint with
displacement on demand
or torque a lot of people mistake it for
a shutter they think the torque
converter or something in the
transmission is creating a vibration
or shuttering during application because
it comes and goes but in reality it's

converter and the lock up clutch and all that stuff works but i'll just give you a two minute brief rundown here
this is the turbine this is connected to the transmission's input shaft to these splines right in here
and connected to the turbine is the torque converter clutch piston this is the piston right here this is
the device that's going to allow for lockup so the engine is going to be able to drive the transmission input shaft through this piston
this portion here is the impeller and it's what moves fluid inside the
torque converter so when the all this is kind of welded together
so when the engine is operating and rotating this device these little hub section here that
drives the oil pump it gets fluid in here but then as this is spinning the fluid is flung from the inside to the out
and the turbine absorbs that fluid and delivers that to the transmission's
input shaft there's a lot of heat and a lot of loss that's occurs in through this process so at some point they apply this
torque converter clutch and that locks up and allows the cover to drive the input shaft
really directly through this piston so what happens on these 6l80s that causes failure
well a lot of people with that displacement on demand always kicking in there's a lot of torsional vibration
that occurs so these springs this hub takes a beating and
it can generate you can generate cracks and so forth and split this this hub assembly up if
you're not careful there can also just be some cracks that are generated inside the hub assembly itself
or even around the turbine or the uh the rivets
so those are issues that could occur another thing is the friction material itself could
fail now the reason why these fails usually because of deflection
and uh talking with the hold on one second i
gotta get a drink
so
had a little tickle on the throat there but so um talking with bob warnke he is a
torque converter expert and he shared some good information about the kind of the pitfalls if you will of
the torque converters and these 6l80s the converter cover and the converter piston
is thin it's it's it's not they built it for weight for probably weight reduction for fuel economy but
they didn't build it build it for robustness so over time these things flex
and they can create cracks and failures even this cover right here
especially if you've got a vehicle that's operate under high load frequently the the mounting pads right here which
are right on the other side were welded right on the other side where the converter clutch lining contacts
they could have flexing and twisting and torsion and that can create them to twist hot
like create high spots right where that converter clutch is in contact with and the woven convert the fiber material that
you have on this converter piston does not like that and has ability or has the
tendency to fracture this lining and cause it to come apart so if you have a transmission that or an
engine that's putting out quite a bit of torque that's causing deflection on these parts
the punishment is taken out on this woven fiber you can see here by looking at that
see if that'll focus in on that yeah it's a woven carbon fiber lining
i'm trying to get my hands so maybe we'll control the focus
so i'm really doing this for the sake of people that maybe have never had a converter apart before so they
don't know they haven't seen this um but yeah that is the woven fiber and
not all aftermarket converters utilize this they might build it with some other
suppliers friction material this carbon fiber is available this woven fiber
woven carbon is available from the oe so you an aftermarket converter builder can use
this friction material it's actually you can buy it from sonic sonic's makes a lot of different friction linings
for converters and they make a they sell the oe lining for this and they use it on some of their upgraded
parts too one of the other things that he mentioned is that they machine this piston with a
little bit of taper on it and that that way when this piston is applying because there's quite a bit of force i mean think of
the pressure that gets placed behind this piston when it gets pushed up against the cover
since the contact is on the outside the piston is going to have a little deflection so to kind of combat that they taper
this piston a little bit so that the at the very beginning the outer portion contacts first and as pressure increases it'll flatten
that piston out and then you'll have full contact with the friction material but that becomes an issue is if you over
pressurize if you have too much pressure in there it'll over deflect the piston and it'll actually curl up outward and then you'll
only be contacting this inner surface so pressures are very important when you're dealing with this
transmission and that kind of brings us to our our next topic is modifying these
things so that way if you're having to deal with converter failure or prevent
converter failure what could you do what is available with a kind of options are available

effective a lot of people are saying that you do need to increase your torque over clutch pressure that you can't just lower your slip
speed to zero and expect it to do it if you test drive it you'll find that your slip speed is probably still higher than zero
which means you need to increase your torque over clutch pressure which you can do with the tuning software
now if i had an oe lining i don't know i'd probably still use slip but i would definitely still change my

the performance converter kit well one of them just as an example and it's got a billet cover
billet piston and a couple friction discs in there so you got more friction surface area by putting two discs in
there you got a thicker billet piston you got a thicker billet cover so you're you're you're fixing the um
the you're fixing the deflection that occurs in the piston and in the cover and you're also increasing your surface

the magnet so it's got quite a bit of metal in this thing and uh I'm assuming most that

and it's slipping so that's likely uh the torque converter coming apart and so

transfer the data if you exceed that one
then it takes three times as long to
transfer the data so the idea behind
that is is the least amount of data that
we are transmitting from the vehicle to
the software they should have the

uh basically what this video is going to

auto shift or up shift automatically
into the next gear when the car is put
into manual mode and basically um the

users to use either the gear shifter or
the paddle shifters on the steering

but in this case we're just going to
focus on downshifting only into a
preferred gear so let's say you're on

do a 40 mile per hour roll race

downshift all the way to second gear

factory tune you're going to be stuck in
that second gear so as soon as you floor
it the car is going to go through up the
rpms and hit redline and bounce off the

paddle shifter or the gear selector
itself

you

the rev limiter anyway and uh pretty
much just kind of hang in that gear for
a split second before it commands the
next shift so that can screw you out of
a race

I'm Matt with Matt's Transmission here today to  demonstrate JASPER's TCC programming package that  
they continue. So on the 6L80 6L90 one problem,  and the main issue, is torque converter apply,  
and how it works. So what this is going to do  actually is JASPER has set this up to where  
it's going to eliminate the TCC apply in the  early gears - in second, third, and fourth.  
So it's going to apply it just in fifth and  sixth. So what that's going to do is reduce  
the wear on the torque converter, and also the  load on that. You get a different load apply  
in second than you do in fifth. So that's  going to really help out that converter,  
the longevity of it, make it drive a lot better.  All right, so first thing you want to do download  
the TDN app on your smartphone; really easy to do,  simple. Next thing you want to do is make sure on  
your vehicle that it has the latest part number  or software for that vehicle. You don't want an  
old part number, so after that you want to plug  everything up and read all the information out of  
that vehicle before you take that transmission  out. What you're wanting to do is get all the  
calibration, everything, all the software out of  that vehicle and put it on this device. For this,  
plug your RTD device into the OBD port;  wait for the green light to come on.
There you go. Okay, so here's your TDN app.  What you're going to want to do number one is  
set up an account. Real easy and simple just like  you always do if you've downloaded apps before,  
it's no big deal. Then you're going  to want to go into the account,  
go to invite code, and then install your code.  Okay, so before you pull the transmission out  
you need to read the vehicle. Go  to the flash button on the bottom,  
please plug in the RTD device, turn the ignition  on, hit OK, and you will read the vehicle. Now  
this will take care of all the information that  you need before you pull the transmission out.  
Okay guys, on a little tip on these push button GM  units to keep the key on while you are doing this  
procedure, you have to hold the button down keep  it pressed down until the dash displays lights.
There you go.  
That'll stay on as long as until you want  to push that button off. Just a little tip.  
Okay, so what you want to do is just read the  vehicle, and pull out all the information.  
Okay, so this is what it's going to look like  after you read the vehicle to the app. Okay,  
so once you have the transmission out, and  actually you install your new transmission,  
you've got everything buttoned up, one thing I  want to make a key point is make sure you have a  
battery maintenance charger, or a charger hooked  to the vehicle. The key will be on for several  
several minutes. Okay, so once you get the  transmission in, you have your RTD hooked up to  
Bluetooth, you're going to go to the bottom of the  screen here, press the flash button, or flash tab,  
select the vehicle that you're working on, and  then you're going to go down to sync files. Once  
you sync that up it's gonna just start reading  the files, and go from there. Okay, so once it  
brings you to this screen you're going to select  the TCC, or actually it says 2014+ 6L80E TCC  
template which is on the bottom there. Once you  select that you're going to select Write Vehicle.
Follow the prompts,  
and there you go. So once you see this screen  you're pretty much done. What you're going to  
do just hit OK, and you are ready to unplug your  RTD device, and start the vehicle. All right guys,  
so once you get to that last screen, you've  hit OK, unplug the device, turn the key off.  
Once you get done just give this to the customer.  This is theirs. This has all their information on  
it. Keep it in the vehicle, whether you want to  hand it to them straight, or just put it in the  
glove box, however they want to do. But this is  their device to keep. Guys, not only do I choose

this is a question that i get a lot just a general cam question if the heads are using are done gaining fluid for
450 to 500 lift like for instance a vortech head of vortex small block chevy
head would it be beneficial to keep the cam around 500 lift for valve train stability
the valve train stability has nothing to do with what the head flow is doing um and you can run more lift in the
camshaft and the head and you'll still gain power even if the head flow levels off and even if it
starts going down past that lift number so like if you stall at 450 and
500 and it goes down at 550 you can still gain power from running a 550 lift
cam because the thing is you've you've added a whole another section of flow and it's only at 550 once during
while it's opening and closing but now you've added another 500 number on the other side of it so
you've gained like average flow and that and that works it doesn't work all the time but
it but it can work so there are a lot of guys that that's a that's a hard and fast rule for them oh
this thing only flows to 550 lift i only need a 550 lift cam and that's that's not true
uh perry that's not a lot of camshaft for a 383 so if you 450 crank horsepower is going to need a

102 intake and ran up to 8000 a couple things there there would be no
comparison between an ls3 intake and the btr short runner intake they're
designed for completely different things the ls3 intake is designed for like a 6500 rpm
power range that's where it's going to be have optimized power production the short runner btr manifold is way
above that so that you would use them for different things if you were running an ls3 manifold up to 8000 you wouldn't be making any power
it's it's way on the fall off side for that runner length and and conversely if you're running a
btr intake and you want to run it at 3000 rpm it's going to be way down compared to a fast manifold because it's
the wrong rpm for that manifold

sooner but it's not at all like it's not anything anywhere near like a turbo does

rigged in jimmy garage can you run 11.9 static compression with an 8.8 dynamic compression on 91 octane well
the dynamic compression is not the thing that's going to determine whether or not that's going to detonate it's not the only thing there are a lot of things
that are going to determine whether that if you if you soften the chamber you could probably
get away with more than that you could probably get away with a higher dynamic if you take timing out of it you can easily run it on 91
but then it's not really going to make a whole bunch of power so the a lot of guys live and live and die
by this dynamic compression thing and they don't realize that that's i mean the air temperature can change it the water temperature can change it
the shape of the chamber the shape of the piston hot spots bad fuel all kinds of things can change
whether or not that's going to work or
